content:
Ever felt like building AI is handing over your soul to a data monster? ğŸ‘¹ I have.

Building IrisGo.AI, a privacy-first AI assistant, has been a tightrope walk. Early on, we faced a critical decision: train our models on user data, like everyone else, or find a better way. The allure of rapid improvement via user data was *strong*. We could have significantly accelerated our development.

Butâ€¦ then what? Weâ€™d be compromising the very promise we were making to our users: that their data *stays* theirs. Imagine explaining that to a user after preaching about privacy! The cognitive dissonance alone kept me up at night.

Instead, we doubled down on synthetic data generation and federated learning. It's been slower, no question. More complex. Way more frustrating at times. But itâ€™s allowed us to build a powerful AI without becoming a data hoarder. ğŸ›¡ï¸

The takeaway? Speed isn't everything. As builders in the AI space, we have a responsibility to design ethical, privacy-respecting systems *from the ground up*. It's harder, yes, but it's also the only sustainable way forward. Building trust is paramount, and that starts with respecting user privacy, even when it's inconvenient.

What are *your* biggest ethical considerations when building AI? I'm keen to hear your thoughts.

What if the biggest risk in a startup is actually *not* failing but *overâ€‘focusing on growth*? At IrisGo.AI, weâ€™ve seen founders chase runway extensions, burn through capital, and chase user metrics, only to find the product stuck in a featureâ€‘addiction loop.

The real danger is building a ship that canâ€™t navigate the market because weâ€™ve never asked the hard questions about who actually needs it.

Iâ€™ve spent the last three years pivoting our AIâ€‘driven imaging platform from â€œmore featuresâ€ to â€œbetter user outcomes.â€ When we shifted to validate useâ€‘cases first, our churn dropped 40% and we raised a smaller, more strategic Series A.

Whatâ€™s your biggest risk in scaling? Share your thoughts or letâ€™s discuss how to keep the product-market fit alive while still growing.

#Startup #Entrepreneurship #BuildInPublic
